Dialogue: I have forgiven them.

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: Nun! These boys still have their weapons, Sister. Your forgiveness will leave blood in its wake. What if they do it to other nuns? Other virgins? Old women who die from the shock? Do you have the rights let these boys go free? Can you bear the burden. Sister?

Speaker: nun
Dialogue: I have prayed for days, Lieutenant. I have prayed for the souls of the boys who raped me. And I have prayed for my own soul, too. I know what I must do. And I know what I must not do.  But you -- you -- it is you who needs to pray. Now, why do you want to kill these boys? Why -- really?

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: Look. Sister. No one has to get killed. We can solve this together. You and me -- as one. These boys are lost sheep. Both Catholic -- did you know that? And they're sick, Sister. With a stress of the mind and of the soul. They need help. Not just jail. Not just psychiatry. They need the help that only the Church can give. Please help me to help them. Help me find them before the others do. The night is full of evil men, chasing these boys with guns and clubs. We have charity and love on our side. I know that together, we could find them first, even in the dark...

Speaker: nun
Dialogue: The good reasons are not always the real reasons. Talk to Jesus, Lieutenant. Pray.  You do you believe in God -- don't you? That Jesus Christ died for your sins?

Speaker: jesus
Dialogue: I forgive you.

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: Me?

Speaker: jesus
Dialogue: I forgive you.

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: You can't forgive me. After what I've done.  I've fucked up bigtime. I've been bad. Real bad.

Speaker: jesus
Dialogue: I forgive you.

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: Please. Please don't forgive me. I've always hated you for that.

Speaker: jesus
Dialogue: I forgive you.

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: Why? Why can't you hate me? Hate me! Please! Help me!  Hate me! Help me! Hate me!

Speaker: jesus
Dialogue: I forgive you.

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: Why? Jesus! Why me? Why can't I wash the ashes from my forehead, year after year after year? And why am I still drunk on your blood, the taste of your flesh on my tongue? Worst of all, why can't I feel the nails in my palms, the spear in my side, the crown of thorns round my head? Why do I have to know, over and over, that it was you. You who died; died for my sins! And that I will die for nothing. Why?

Speaker: jesus
Dialogue: I forgive you.

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: Why do I dream every night of the whore who brought you water on your road to death? And why have I never forgotten that if she, then I --

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: Oh God, my God. it's goddamn good to be good. Forgive me. Father, for I have sinned. It's still goddamn good to be good.

Speaker: jesus
Dialogue: I forgive you.

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: The chalice. Tell me! Who gave it to you! Tell me where the fuck you got it! Take me there! Now!

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: In the name of God, you must.

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: We've already got Hell, Sister.

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: No. Not a cop.

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: A holy thing.  Let's go.

Speaker: fence
Dialogue: You took the chalice.

Speaker: fence
Dialogue: You brought it back to the Church. And then it made it's way back to me, again.

Speaker: fence
Dialogue: I was gonna bring it back myself.

Speaker: fence
Dialogue: Jesus, woman! What did you think? You thought I'd get mad like I did that time you took that set of pots and pans? That was twenty years ago. And how do you compare pots and pans and a chalice?

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: They both hold stuff you eat.

Speaker: fence
Dialogue: So what are you doing here?

Speaker: fence
Dialogue: That's no mystery. Julio and Paolo brought it in,  No. How could you understand.

Speaker: fence
Dialogue: Well -- maybe you do. But I don't know where those boys are at right now. You'll have to ask around. Those boys on the corner'll know. You'll have to get it out of them. But they know.

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: Thank you. And I'll make sure the chalice gets back where it belongs.

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: Hey -- Have you seen Paolo or Julio around?

Speaker: street dealer
Dialogue: What the fuck you want.

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: You know, my Uncle used to wear a walkman all the time. The walkman looked just like yours. And you look something like my Uncle. But one day he was standing in a puddle -- the puddle locked just like that one --

Speaker: street dealer
Dialogue: And what?

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: And he got electrocuted.

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: Look -- I don't know you, and you don't know me, but I'm really in the mood to kill someone today and you are at the end of my gun.  Tell me! Where is Julio and Paolo ?

Speaker: street dealer
Dialogue: They were at that abandoned building last night. Second floor. They're probably still there now. It's next to the old Convent. Downtown a ways. You know the place...

Speaker: julio
Dialogue: Who the fu--

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: Shut up. Let's watch the game.

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: Strawberry...

Speaker: paolo
Dialogue: Yeah...

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: Give me the robes.

Speaker: julio
Dialogue: You're not a cop are you?

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: Jesus died for your sins, you motherfuckers! Not me. No. I didn't die for your sins. No, not me. Jesus went and did it.  So why did you do what you did? If you want to live, tell me now, motherfuckers! Tell me now!

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: I forgive you.

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: Get out.

Speaker: lt
Dialogue: If you think you're not getting on this bus, you're dead wrong. No fucking way are you gonna miss this bus, man! You were probably the kind of kids who had your father drive you to school cause you couldn't catch the fucking bus. But no more, man. You're getting on this bus and you're taking it to the last fucking stop. So get on the fucking bus, man, 'cause you're life ain't worth shit in this town.
